channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: “Tax the Rich” Echoes 10 Years After Occupy Wall Street
item.description: Occupy’s legacyPeople disagree about the long-term impact of Occupy Wall Street, with some calling it a flop and others arguing that it laid the groundwork for other progressive social and political movements.    On September 17, 2011, Occupy Wall Street began. —NF “I think if you look at the last 10 years, activism has not worked,” he said.  In 2011, Time magazine named “The Protestor” as its Person of the Year.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Microsoft Goes Completely Passwordless
item.description: It’s much harder to swipe a user’s fingerprint or a code sent directly to their phone. —MM Bottom line: Microsoft said that the rapid shift to digital during the pandemic accelerated its timeline for the rollout.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 16
item.description: More people visited the park last month—921,844—than in any August on record, park officials said. (Julia Hobsbawm on Twitter) Watch: An excellent back-to-office video.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Canva Becomes the Fifth-Most Valuable Private Startup in the World
item.description: —MM Canva will use the new funding to double its 2,000-person staff over the next year and expand into web design and video editing tools.  Looking ahead...
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Casino Stocks Plunge Over Fears of a Crackdown on Macau
item.description: US casino stocks with exposure to Macau, such as Wynn, also tumbled yesterday. —NF Macau’s casinos rake in around $37 billion in annual revenue, roughly 5x more than the Vegas Strip. Zoom out: Macau is to Las Vegas as Las Vegas is to Atlantic City. less gambling.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Food Delivery Apps Are Suing NYC and Other Cities
item.description: What delivery apps like DoorDash are angry about is that leaders in NYC and SF traced over their commission cap laws in Sharpie even after restaurants reopened. The other lawsuit, which saw DoorDash, GrubHub, and Uber Eats join forces, concerns commission caps, or the percentage of a food order’s total that delivery apps can charge restaurants for their services.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Canva Becomes the Fifth-Most Valuable Private Startup in the World
item.description: —MM Canva will use the new funding to double its 2,000-person staff over the next year and expand into web design and video editing tools.  Looking ahead...

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 16
item.description: More people visited the park last month—921,844—than in any August on record, park officials said. (Julia Hobsbawm on Twitter) Watch: An excellent back-to-office video.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Casino Stocks Plunge Over Fears of a Crackdown on Macau
item.description: US casino stocks with exposure to Macau, such as Wynn, also tumbled yesterday. A Bloomberg index of the six Macau casino operators plummeted 23%, the biggest one-day fall on record. —NF Macau’s casinos rake in around $37 billion in annual revenue, roughly 5x more than the Vegas Strip.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Food Delivery Apps Are Suing NYC and Other Cities
item.description: What delivery apps like DoorDash are particularly angry about is that leaders in NYC and San Francisco traced over their commission cap laws in Sharpie even after restaurants reopened. The other lawsuit, which saw DoorDash, GrubHub, and Uber Eats join forces, concerns commission caps, or the percentage of a food order’s total that delivery apps can charge restaurants for their services.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Amazon Will Hire a Hartford, CT
item.description: Amazon said it will add 125,000 delivery and warehouse workers in the US ahead of the busy holiday shopping season. Pretty soon, everyone will be an Amazon employee. Well, Amazon plans to open 100 new logistics facilities this month alone. – NF
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 15
item.description: Quote: “Starting with boosters, especially giving it to healthy populations, is really not right.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Knows Instagram is Toxic to Teens, Leaked Documents Reveal
item.description: “People talk about Instagram like it’s a drug.  Leaked documents reviewed by WSJ show that, despite knowing the harmful impacts of Instagram on teens, Facebook has taken few actions to make it less toxic and protect its most vulnerable users.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Apple Decides 2021 Isn’t a Year to Take Risks
item.description: Big picture: Apple’s event comes just days after a judge forced the company to make the biggest change to the App Store since it was created in 2008. But besides a larger battery, a faster chip, and a smaller “notch” at the top of the screen, users won’t find that much difference between the new model and the iPhone 12.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: SpaceX’s All-Civilian Crew Prepares for Liftoff
item.description: Why it matters: This mission, SpaceX’s Inspiration4, is far more ambitious and technically difficult than the other billionaires’ space flights this summer. Zoom out: Through its Commercial Crew Program, NASA invested billions in both Boeing and SpaceX to get commercial space flight off the ground. Who’s joining him:Hayley Arceneaux, a cancer survivor and physician assistant at St. Jude, will become the youngest person ever to go to space at 29, and the first with a prosthetic body part.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 15
item.description: Quote: “Starting with boosters, especially giving it to healthy populations, is really not right.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Amazon Will Hire a Hartford, CT
item.description: Amazon said it will add 125,000 delivery and warehouse workers in the US ahead of the busy holiday shopping season.  One out of every 153 employed workers in the US works for Amazon, per Business Insider. Pretty soon, everyone will be an Amazon employee.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Apple Decides 2021 Isn’t a Year to Take Risks
item.description: For more Apple: Read this Twitter thread about how Apple created its famous “walled garden.” What else did Apple announce? But besides a larger battery, a faster chip, and a smaller “notch” at the top of the screen, users won’t find that much difference between the new model and the iPhone 12.

Who’s joining him:Hayley Arceneaux, a cancer survivor and physician assistant at St. Jude, will become the youngest person ever to go to space at 29, and the first with a prosthetic body part.

item.title: Colossal Raises $15 Million to Repopulate Siberia With Woolly Mammoths
item.description: A new company called Colossal intends to re-create and re-introduce the extinct woolly mammoth to the Siberian tundra. – NF But it’ll have to navigate an ethical minefield to get there. Looking ahead... OK, but why?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 14
item.description: Stat: Jason Sudeikis will make nearly $1 million per episode for season 3 of Ted Lasso, according to the Hollywood Reporter. (WSJ)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What to Know about California's Recall Election
item.description: Here's where things stand right now:The latest polls compiled by FiveThirtyEight show Newsom with a sizeable lead. California, the most populous state in the US and the fifth-largest economy in the world, will decide today whether Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom should remain in office. – SQ But few have prompted an election and only six officials have actually been recalled.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Walmart’s Crypto Partnership Is Lite on Truth
item.description: Intrado, the company that operates GlobeNewswire, said it is looking into how the fake release, which even included a made-up quote from Walmart’s CEO, got through its filters. – NF Everyone went into clean-up mode: Litecoin’s creator said its social media manager was “wrong to retweet” the announcement.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: House Democrats Propose $2.9 Trillion in Tax Increases
item.description: This tax proposal is seen as an olive branch to moderate Democrats who don’t want to play the villain to business. On the spicy scale, this plan is mildWhile it reverses many of the Republican tax cuts for 2018, the plan stops short of the ambitious tax hikes President Biden first proposed. Americans who earn more than $435,000 per year would see their top tax rate increase from 37% to 39.6%. House Democrats are all of us before wedding season as they scramble to cover the bill for their pricey $3.5 trillion budget proposal. – MM
item.author: Matty Merritt

California, the most populous state in the US and the fifth-largest economy in the world, will decide today whether Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom should remain in office. – SQ But few have prompted an election and only six officials have actually been recalled.

item.title: House Democrats Propose $2.9 Trillion in Tax Increases
item.description: This tax proposal is seen as an olive branch to moderate Democrats who don’t want to play the villain to business. On the spicy scale, this plan is mildWhile it reverses many of the Republican tax cuts for 2018, the plan stops short of the ambitious tax hikes President Biden first proposed. Americans who earn more than $435,000 per year would see their top tax rate increase from 37% to 39.6%. House Democrats are all of us before wedding season as they scramble to cover the bill for their pricey $3.5 trillion budget proposal. – MM
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The Future Of Business Travel? The Experts at Morning Brew & Hilton—And You—Weigh In
item.description: Taking the Work Out of Work TravelThe infusion of biz travel with leisure activities—say it with us, bleisure—was popular pre-pandemic, but may become more of the norm as travelers make the most of these moments to work from virtually anywhere. * BTW: If you are not already a Hilton Honors member, it’s free to join, and new members can earn up to 5,000 Bonus Points through the end of the year. And there’s a very, very good chance it’ll have a lasting impact on what business travel looks like for years to come. With 48% of readers saying that loyalty program points and rewards were things they most looked forward to when traveling, it’s clear that perks will have even extra oomph as biz travel resumes.   Travel has its perks. New cardmembers can earn up to 180,000 Bonus Points*—equivalent to 4 FREE nights at more than 4,600 Hilton hotels worldwide—and get Hilton Honors Gold Status (hello complimentary room upgrades) AND earn Points at places like U.S. supermarkets, gas stations and restaurants. Turns out, Morning Brew readers miss business travel too. Paired with insights from Hilton’s Global Head of Marketing & Loyalty Mark Weinstein, and our resident travel expert, Elyssa, we uncovered what you miss most about business travel (hello, alone time) —and what it could mean for the future. But the pandemic has pushed us to reconsider its purpose and pushed hotels like Hilton to reconsider their role in travelers’ lives, placing even more importance on meeting both their emotional and functional needs and desires, according to Weinstein. Hilton for example offered hotel rooms for guests to increase efficiency in their workday, and several hotels ran offers to allow business professionals to stay, work and play for an extended period of time. To appeal to new WFH travelers, hotels adapted by offering ideal working spaces and access to local coworking spots. With video calls being our M.O. for so long, business travel moving forward may be viewed less as a chore and more like a special treat.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: The Week Ahead: September 13
item.description: California recall: CA Governor Gavin Newsom faces a high-stakes recall election on Tuesday. New iPhones: Tomorrow, Apple will hold its fall hardware event, where it’s expected to introduce the iPhone 13, new Apple Watches and AirPods, and more.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: (Craftsmanship Quarterly) Read: Eco-fashion's animal rights delusion. Bush explicitly linked the 9/11 terrorists with the Americans who attacked the Capitol building on Jan. 6.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Remote Workers Get Siloed at their Companies, Microsoft Study Shows
item.description: Zoom out: The research was published as most of the country’s biggest tech companies push off a return to the office in light of the Delta variant.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Norway Heads to the Polls in Pivotal Election for the Environment
item.description: But unlike in the US, smaller political parties in Norway hold major sway.   And how those groups, which advocate for a more immediate break from fossil fuels, fare in the election will ultimately decide how quickly Norway severs ties to an industry that made it so rich.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden Expands Production of At-Home Covid Tests, Where the US Is Behind
item.description: Zoom out: Michael Mina, a Harvard epidemiologist who’s been arguing for more at-home tests since last year, said Biden’s plan was a “good start,” but it still represents less than one test per American over the course of a year.  Even India, which has fewer resources than the US, is selling rapid tests for $3.50.  Problem is, in the US over-the-counter rapid tests are expensive and scarce.
item.author: Neal Freyman
